item.title: Stellan Skarsgard on ‘Sentimental Value’ and His Wide-Ranging Career
item.description: After a stroke four years ago, the actor has changed how he approaches performances, including the one he’s become an awards favorite for.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Jason Nocito
item.media:credit: Jason Nocito for The New York Times

item.title: Harry Melling Went From PG ‘Harry Potter’ to B.D.S.M. ‘Pillion’
item.description: The actor Harry Melling shed his image as Harry’s cruel cousin, Dudley Dursley — and his clothes — to star in the queer romance “Pillion.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Jono White for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British actor Harry Melling became known for a role in the “Harry Potter” movies. Now he stars in the kinky romantic comedy “Pillion.”

item.title: 10 Movies to Stream for Black History Month
item.description: Watch these selections that highlight the range and evolution of Black film.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: ‘Starman’ Review: What’s Really Out There?
item.description: The theories laid out by the aerospace engineer Gentry Lee in this new documentary may blow your mind.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: In ‘Nadja,’ Dracula’s Daughter Goes Downtown
item.description: This triumph of low-budget filmmaking will shimmer for a week at Brooklyn Academy of Music.
item.dc:creator: J. Hoberman
item.media:description: Karl Geary as Renfield and Elina Lowensohn as Nadja, right, in “Nadja.”

item.title: ‘Melania’ Review: 20 Stage-Managed Days in the Life of the First Lady
item.description: Directed by Brett Ratner, the documentary shows a woman deeply concerned with her appearance who rarely lets us behind her facade.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Catherine O’Hara Was Always a Delight
item.description: The Emmy-winning actress was especially adept at playing women who had been cast off but maintained an inflated sense of self, always with a great comedic payoff.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in “Home Alone,” the movie in which many first saw her comic gifts.

item.title: Yahya Abdul-Mateen II Starts His Days With This Podcast
item.description: “It’s basically professional barbershop talk with an unfiltered delivery,” said the star of the new Marvel series “Wonder Man.”
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in February
item.description: A new series from the creator of “Derry Girls” and an inside look at the world of competitive ice dancing are among the highlights this month.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: From left, Caoilfhionn Dunne, Roisin Gallagher and Sinead Keenan in a scene from “How to Get to Heaven From Belfast.”

item.title: ‘Solo Mio’ Review: Wishful Thinking in Italy
item.description: After being left at the altar, Matt (Kevin James) finds himself alone in Rome. But don’t worry, he’ll quickly find an Italian woman to fall for him.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh

item.title: Best Movies and Shows Streaming in February 2026
item.description: The docuseries “Soul Power” and “The Muppet Show” arrive, and “Dark Winds,” “Monarch: Legacy of Monsters,” “Scrubs” and “John Oliver” return.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.category: Last Week Tonight With John Oliver (TV Program)

item.title: Demond Wilson, Long-Suffering Son on ‘Sanford and Son,’ Dies at 79
item.description: As Lamont, he was a young man in constant battle with his father and business partner, played by Redd Foxx, on the popular 1970s series.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:credit: NBCU Photo Bank, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Wilson, left, in 1972 on “Sanford and Son” with Redd Foxx, who played his character’s father.

item.title: How Lesley Manville Is Leaving ‘Oedipus’ Audiences Spellbound
item.description: Personal history emerges by painful degrees in “Oedipus,” whose language and story, the actress Lesley Manville says, “wreck me every time.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:description: Lesley Manville portrays Jocasta in Robert Icke’s retelling of the Greek tragedy.

item.title: Where to Watch Catherine O’Hara’s Best Performances, From ‘Beetlejuice’ to ‘Best in Show’
item.description: Her characters were as varied as they were eccentric and lovable. These are some of the best.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara won a best lead actress Emmy for her role as the down-and-out former millionaire Moira Rose in the sitcom “Schitt’s Creek.”

item.title: Catherine O’Hara: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The Canadian actress’s career spanned decades and genres, including memorable roles in “Home Alone” and “Schitt’s Creek.”
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara photographed in 1986 in Los Angeles.

item.title: 6 Takeaways from ‘Melania,’ the Melania Trump Documentary
item.description: The film, which counts Melania Trump as a producer, touches on her immigrant roots, her love for her mother and her style, but there are few revelations.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: Macaulay Culkin And Others Pay Tribute to Catherine O’Hara After Her Death
item.description: Videos and photos filled social media as fans shared their favorite scenes from O’Hara’s acting career and co-stars memorialized her.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019. The actress died this week at the age of 71.

item.title: Roger Allers Dies at 76; Helped Put ‘Lion King’ on Screens and Onstage
item.description: A Disney fan who once “flew” off his couch as a 4-year-old Peter Pan, he was a co-director of the animated film and a co-writer of the Broadway musical, both of them megahits.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Roger Allers in 2023. “He was extraordinarily visual, had a great story sense and a beautiful design sense,” a colleague said.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, ‘Home Alone’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Actress, Dies at 71
item.description: An Emmy-winning comedian with oddball charm, she got her start with the influential Canadian sketch comedy series “SCTV.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

item.title: The Last Sundance in Park City Ends on an Aptly Misty Moment
item.description: At the conclusion of a mixed festival, John Turturro and Giancarlo Esposito, co-stars in a new drama, reminded us of why the event matters.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.category: Once Upon a Time in Harlem (Movie)

item.title: How Timothée Chalamet Makes His Point in ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: The director Josh Safdie discusses a table tennis moment from his film, featuring Chalamet, Gwyneth Paltrow and Geza Rohrig.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a disastrous vacation, a macabre homecoming and a witchy healing session.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: ‘Marty Supreme’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Josh Safdie narrates a sequence from his film, nominated for nine Oscars and featuring Timothée Chalamet and Gwyneth Paltrow.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Brett Ratner Makes Directing Comeback With ‘Melania’
item.description: Once a reliable Hollywood hitmaker, Mr. Ratner hasn’t directed a film since accusations of sexual misconduct in 2017 that he denied.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: “Melania,” a documentary made in partnership with the first lady, is the first film directed by Brett Ratner in nearly 12 years.

item.title: ‘Natchez’: Histories Clash in a Complex Look at the City
item.description: Suzannah Herbert’s film centers on antebellum mansions and the narratives the owners want to tell about the South.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘The Karate Kid’ and ‘Clueless’ Join National Film Registry
item.description: These films, along with “White Christmas” and “Inception,” are among 25 selected by the Librarian of Congress this year.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Alicia Silverstone in “Clueless,” directed by Amy Heckerling.

item.title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
item.description: In this month’s picks, mountain climbing, dog sledding and government running.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: Alex Honnold, the subject of “Free Solo.”

item.title: Before Tilly Norwood, This C.G.I. Actress Was Considered an ‘It Girl’
item.description: Aki Ross was the computer-generated heroine of the 2001 film “Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within.” The reaction at the time presaged today’s debate over A.I.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar

item.title: ‘Shelter’ Review: Jason Statham Dispatches Enemies From a Lighthouse
item.description: A teenage girl gets stuck on an island with a rogue MI5 agent. Then, international assassins come after them.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Worldbreaker’ Review: Smashed to Bits
item.description: This postapocalyptic father-daughter story shamelessly recombines overused ideas.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Send Help’ Review: Rachel McAdams Transforms in Dark Comedy
item.description: A mousy employee and her odious boss battle for dominance in this jubilantly wicked thriller.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘A Poet’ Review: The Romance of Misery
item.description: A once-promising writer learns some painful lessons in a tragicomic Colombian tale.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Paying for It’ Review: Opening Up the Relationship
item.description: Sonny starts bringing in new lovers, so Chester finds a solution: He starts hiring prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Azzopardi

item.title: ‘Moses the Black’ Review: An Overcooked Crucible
item.description: Omar Epps struggles to grant this gangland Chicago religious drama divine quality.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: ‘The Moment’ Review: Charli XCX Laughs Last
item.description: The movie glances at artistic concerns like autonomy and authenticity while gleefully testing the divide between a public and a private self.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘The Love That Remains’ Review: Time Goes On
item.description: A family navigates the year after parents separate in this funny, surrealist Icelandic drama.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Islands’ Review: A Thriller Fit for a Volcanic Island
item.description: This slow-burn tale of a tennis pro and a couple gets the low-grade melancholy of a resort town right.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy
